course.subject: MATH
course.name: Introduction to Lie Groups
course.description: General linear groups, orthogonal groups, unitary groups, symplectic groups, exponential maps, maximal tori, Clifford algebra, spin groups.
course.prerequisites: (MATH 2010 OR MATH 2011 OR MATH 2021 OR MATH 2023 OR MATH 3043) AND (MATH 2111 OR MATH 2121 OR MATH 2131 OR MATH 2350)

reviews.author: agoti
reviews.title: it's what it says on the tin.
reviews.comment_content:
See description.

You want introduction to Lie Groups, you get introduction to Lie Groups.
The content is relatively simple compared to how complex the whole topic is. The in-depth content is given in the textbook (+ a few books given during the lessons), which one can look into if they so desire.

The course is split into 3 parts, as a step-by-step journey (aka: "introduction") to eventually understanding the topic:
1. Representation of Finite Groups
2. Lie Algebra (+ Representations)
3. Lie Groups (+ Representations)

Oh, and the course assumes you know MATH3121/MATH3131 already, despite not having it as prerequisite. I didn't take that course, so I struggled quite a bit.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Is average. The professor occasionally spends a bit of time explaining the background and application of Lie theory (it is an introduction after all), and will ask students to raise questions and comments about the materials taught.
I probably can't say for everyone because of my lack of math background, but I it took me a lot of off-class self-studying to catch up with the things taught.

I'm just *very* glad that the Zoom recordings exist.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got A+, despite failing to understand how the last question of the last homework worked.

Since I don't know what grades other students received, and there are no feedback for the homework whatsoever, I can only assume with a sample size of 1 that the grading is very lax.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 Homework only (questions given during lessons, to be submitted in a week after the chapter ends). No exams.

The homework questions are given as a way for students to "explore" on the topic, and to understand how some of the idea and proofs work. (As the professor said they are kind of like "mini-projects")
If you have enough understanding of how things work (or have watched the lecture enough times to understand the topic and questions), the questions aren't a big problem. I don't, so the homework took me some time. Not that much more than your average math proof-writing course though I guess.
